pull_request.title: proxy: make auth more type safe
pull_request.body:
## Problem

https://github.com/neondatabase/neon/blob/a5292f7e67727307341c1d4a372ee7f69efbb626/proxy/src/auth/backend.rs#L146-L148

https://github.com/neondatabase/neon/blob/a5292f7e67727307341c1d4a372ee7f69efbb626/proxy/src/console/provider/neon.rs#L90

https://github.com/neondatabase/neon/blob/a5292f7e67727307341c1d4a372ee7f69efbb626/proxy/src/console/provider/neon.rs#L154

## Summary of changes

jank.

we have a `ClientCredentials` that has an optional endpoint, and a `ComputeUserInfo` that has a required endpoint. authenticate takes in a `ClientCredentials` and returns a `ComputeUserInfo`.

It's also mixed in with wake_compute CachedNodeInfo stuff, so it's rather messy...

## Checklist before requesting a review

- [ ] I have performed a self-review of my code.
- [ ] If it is a core feature, I have added thorough tests.
- [ ] Do we need to implement analytics? if so did you add the relevant metrics to the dashboard?
- [ ] If this PR requires public announcement, mark it with /release-notes label and add several sentences in this section.

## Checklist before merging

- [ ] Do not forget to reformat commit message to not include the above checklist

commits.message:
tests: revise perf test that interfered with local disk state (#5682)

This benchmark started failing after #5580 merged.

It was manually deleting some local content on a pageserver, and
expecting the behavior that the pageserver would "forget" about the
timeline on startup as a result. That is no longer our behavior:
pageservers use the remote storage as the source of truth.

Rather than having the test go manually delete things at all, we can
just delete the whole tenant via the pageserver API, and thereby start
from a clean situation.

feat: add `build_tag` env support for `set_build_info_metric` (#5576)

- Add a new util `project_build_tag` macro, similar to
`project_git_version`
- Update the `set_build_info_metric` to accept and make use of
`build_tag` info
- Update all codes which use the `set_build_info_metric`

fix: schedule_compaction_update must only unlink (#5675)

#5649 added the concept of dangling layers which #4938 uses but only
partially. I forgot to change `schedule_compaction_update` to not
schedule deletions to uphold the "have a layer, you can read it".

With the now remembered fix, I don't think these checks should ever fail
except for a mistake I already did. These changes might be useful for
protecting future changes, even though the Layer carrying the generation
AND the `schedule_(gc|compaction)_update` require strong arcs.

Rationale for keeping the `#[cfg(feature = "testing")]` is worsening any
leak situation which might come up.
Grant BYPASSRLS and REPLICATION to exited roles

39f8fd69456ba59e11fec9e6a52beb58f011bef3 at 2023-10-27T10:34:14.065Z :recycle:

To the original:
> So I guess we would now block on evict_and_wait if a compaction was going on and touched some of the layers we're about to evict, right?

No blocking needed. We would just evict or fail to evict regardless of future compaction access (which would start by first acquiring RAII guards keeping the layers resident -- `ResidentLayer`).

pull_request.title: refactor: remove layer_removal_cs
pull_request.body:
Quest: https://github.com/neondatabase/neon/issues/4745. Follow-up to #4938.

- add in locks for compaction and gc, so we don't have multiple executions at the same time in tests
- remove layer_removal_cs
- remove waiting for uploads in eviction/gc/compaction
    - #4938 will keep the file resident until upload completes
    - is this however safe to remove without having backpressure from lack of compactions to wal ingestion?

commits.message:
fix: schedule_compaction_update must only unlink (#5675)

#5649 added the concept of dangling layers which #4938 uses but only
partially. I forgot to change `schedule_compaction_update` to not
schedule deletions to uphold the "have a layer, you can read it".

With the now remembered fix, I don't think these checks should ever fail
except for a mistake I already did. These changes might be useful for
protecting future changes, even though the Layer carrying the generation
AND the `schedule_(gc|compaction)_update` require strong arcs.

Rationale for keeping the `#[cfg(feature = "testing")]` is worsening any
leak situation which might come up.

pull_request.title: fix: schedule_compaction_update must only unlink
pull_request.body:
#5649 added the concept of dangling layers which #4938 uses but only partially. I forgot to change `schedule_compaction_update` to not schedule deletions to uphold the "have a layer, you can read it".

With the now remembered fix, I don't think these checks should ever fail except for a mistake I already did. These changes might be useful for protecting future changes, even though the Layer carrying the generation AND the `schedule_(gc|compaction)_update` require strong arcs.

Rationale for keeping the `#[cfg(feature = "testing")]` is worsening any leak situation which might come up.

auto_merge.commit_message:
#5649 added the concept of dangling layers which #4938 uses but only
partially. I forgot to change `schedule_compaction_update` to not
schedule deletions to uphold the "have a layer, you can read it".

With the now remembered fix, I don't think these checks should ever fail
except for a mistake I already did. These changes might be useful for
protecting future changes, even though the Layer carrying the generation
AND the `schedule_(gc|compaction)_update` require strong arcs.

Rationale for keeping the `#[cfg(feature = "testing")]` is worsening any
leak situation which might come up.

comment.body:
> This may be a bit OT for this PR, but it makes me wonder if we should make the wanted_evicted field hold a timestamp (the access time when eviction decided to evict the layer), and if the layer has been accessed more recently then we shouldn't go through with the eviction. That's obviously an optimization thing rather than a safety thing though.

I did consider that but it is difficult to say would this help. This would move the decision to evict or not to Layer, which I am not keen on doing because you cannot have a full picture there. Theoretically the value is already there. I could add a warning metric for when eviction happens to within one minute accessed Layer.

Currently evictions always lose to re-downloads, meaning that we could have:
1. Layer::evict_and_wait
2. last `Arc<DownloadedLayer>` is dropped, `spawn_blocking` is scheduled
3. before `spawn_blocking` gets to run, there's a new read access to layer contents which gets to run first incrementing the version -- it finds the file locally
4. when spawn_blocking finally gets to run, we notice the version mismatch and eviction is cancelled.

Could be the step 4 is actually a bit racy now that I think of it. Need to check that as well. However this is as designed and as I would like to keep it. Perhaps I just need to get rid of the version field and the "rare metric".

- add in locks for compaction and gc, so we don't have multiple executions at the same time in tests
- remove layer_removal_cs
- remove waiting for uploads in eviction/gc/compaction
    - #4938 will keep the file resident until upload completes
    - is this however safe to remove without having backpressure from lack of compactions to wal ingestion?

review.body:
The tests reusing the original key file path as a directory is a bit confusing but I think it's more ergonomic than to fiddle with the config generation, and it shows we are not sticky with "this used to be a file but it is now a directory, bail!".

I still want that failure in pageserver startup if we fail to read any keys though (~I think it was left unpushed~ [c425c1d](https://github.com/neondatabase/neon/pull/5594/commits/c425c1dc68065c0c67bbbb4cb8479d2e6b4c99a6)).

pull_request.title: Support JWT key reload in pageserver
pull_request.body:
## Problem

For quickly rotating JWT secrets, we want to be able to reload the JWT public key file in the pageserver, and also support multiple JWT keys.

See #4897.

## Summary of changes

* Allow directories for the `auth_validation_public_key_path` config param instead of just files.
* Make the JWT public keys easily globally swappable by using the `arc-swap` crate.
* Add an endpoint to the pageserver, triggered by a POST to `/v1/reload_auth_validation_keys`, that reloads the JWT public keys from the pre-configured path (for security reasons, you cannot upload any keys yourself).

Fixes #4897

## Checklist before requesting a review

- [x] I have performed a self-review of my code.
- [x] If it is a core feature, I have added thorough tests.
- [ ] Do we need to implement analytics? if so did you add the relevant metrics to the dashboard?
- [ ] If this PR requires public announcement, mark it with /release-notes label and add several sentences in this section.

## Checklist before merging

- [ ] Do not forget to reformat commit message to not include the above checklist
